title: Is the phrase 'compare and contrast' somewhat redundant? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, “compare and contrast” isn’t really redundant. If we’re asked to compare two items we may be looking for things they have in common as well as differences. (Though as shown in the definition below, and as mentioned by Justin Franco compare is also often used to refer specifically to similarities.) When asked to contrast them we are specifically looking for differences. Thus when someone asks us to compare and contrast, they are simply making it clear that they want us to consider both the similarities and the differences. I seem to recall seeing a lot of “compare and contrast” questions on literature exams. For example if we were studying Siddhartha by Hermann Hesse and The Ingenious Gentleman Don Quixote of La Mancha by Miguel de Cervantes a teacher might ask us to “Compare and contrast the nature of the quests undertaken by the characters Siddhartha and Don Quixote.” Alas I never had that particular question as we didn’t read the books in the same year. compare - definition of compare in English | Oxford Dictionaries 1 Estimate, measure, or note the similarity or dissimilarity between: 1.1 compare something to Point out or describe the resemblances with; liken to: ‘her novel was compared to the work of Daniel Defoe’ contrast - definition of contrast in English | Oxford Dictionaries Differ strikingly: ‘his friend's success contrasted with his own failure’ ‘a contrasting view’ 1.1[with object] Compare in such a way as to emphasize differences: ‘people contrasted her with her sister’

Technically, no. I know it's pedantic to say technically, but it's true in this sense. Traditionally, when we compare things, we are looking for similarities. When we contrast, we look for differences. So the terms aren't redundant; they're opposites, though modern usage has allowed the word compare to mean finding both similarities and differences.

My professor who teaches English says it is redundant to use compare and contrast together, because ‘compare’ can mean looking at similarities and differences. If I am comparing two different shirts, Im automatically going to look at how they are similar and how they are different; the “contrasting” is already there. And according to Merriam-Webster, compare can be used for differences as well. So, technically, adding ‘contrast’ is redundant, but sometimes it can be used for emphasis. Language is so fluid that saying “compare and contrast” isnt wrong, it’s just more emphatic, I think.

Yes! The dictionary definition of ‘compare’ is to examine two or more things (objects, people, events etc) for similarities *and* differences. Adding ‘contrast’ is unnecessary and therefore redundant. And it keeps people thinking that ‘comparing’ is only about similarities, which just isn’t true. Drop the ‘contrast’!

These are not actually redundant,  since repetition  is one of the better means of communicating ideas. An effective communicator  brings greater clarity to any subject by the employment of synonymous terms  and  a multitude of examples. Of course,  a person  could make the point that  a  single term  can suffice for a  briefer explanation, and yet there is no objective reason  shown that informs people that  brevity is better in all circumstances.
